`acceptsFrom` is used in #11311 to define left quotients.

Sorry about the wait! Should be ready for review again. PTAL!
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by YaelDillies.
bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9930388293/job/27429068855)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9930388293/job/27429068928)
maintainer merge
Use of dot notation should not change the name of the lemma. A lemma of the form `(foo a).bar = _` should be called `bar_foo`, not `foo_bar`.
maintainer merge

I don't think you need `mem_accepts'`
```suggestion
theorem mem_accepts (x : List Î±) : x âˆˆ M.accepts â†” M.eval x âˆˆ M.accept := by rfl
#align DFA.mem_accepts DFA.mem_accepts
```
Sounds good. It was used in `pumping_lemma` but I replaced it with `rw [mem_accepts, eval]`.

No need specifying universes unless you're doing category theory
```suggestion
section Map
variable {Î±' Ïƒ' : Type*} (f : Î± â‰ƒ Î±') (g : Ïƒ â‰ƒ Ïƒ') (s : Ïƒ') (a : Î±') (x : List Î±')
```
Done. It might be worth removing the existing universe declarations, but that can be done in another PR
We usually use `congr` for this instead, eg `FreeGroup.freeGroupCongr` (which is not a great name either, but still)

```suggestion
theorem equiv_accepts : (equiv f g M).accepts = List.map f.symm â»Â¹' M.accepts := by
```
Using the preimage of the inverse instead of the image has (usually) better definitional properties.

Should this be a preimage by `h` instead? Either way, I think the docstring needs to be clearer about the semantics of this operation, since I can't tell from it whether preimage or image is more correct.
I suspect the answer is that we should have (at least) two things: `map : DFA Î± Ïƒ -> DFA Î±' Ïƒ` and `reindex : DFA Î± Ïƒ ~= DFA Î± Ïƒ'`

Thanks both! Agree with the preimage. It does seem nicer not having an existential.

I take @YaelDillies' naming suggestion, except I call the former `comap`, since the mapping function goes "backwards". (Similar to `SimpleGraph.comap`.) I also considered adding an equiv version for the alphabet but that's just `âŸ¨comap f, comap f.symmâŸ©` so not very interesting.
Can you add a lemma about `equiv refl refl` and `(equiv e f).symm = equiv e.symm f.symm`?
Added these for `comap` and `reindex`.
Can you add a lemma that says `reindex` and `comap` commute?
can `simps` generate these?
Huh, I thought `simps` doesn't work on `Equiv`, but it turns out it does!

Nevermind. The `@[simps]` attribute generates `reindex_symm_step` etc. which conflict with the manually defined `reindex_symm`.

```
/- The `simpNF` linter reports:
SOME SIMP LEMMAS ARE NOT IN SIMP-NORMAL FORM.
see note [simp-normal form] for tips how to debug this.
https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib_docs/notes.html#simp-normal%20form -/
-- Mathlib.Computability.DFA
Error: ./././Mathlib/Computability/DFA.lean:219:3: error: DFA.reindex_symm_apply_step.{u_1, u, v} simp can prove this:
  by simp only [@DFA.reindex_symm, @DFA.reindex_apply_step, @Equiv.symm_symm]
One of the lemmas above could be a duplicate.
If that's not the case try reordering lemmas or adding @[priority].

Error: ./././Mathlib/Computability/DFA.lean:219:3: error: DFA.reindex_symm_apply_accept.{u_1, u, v} simp can prove this:
  by simp only [@DFA.reindex_symm, @DFA.reindex_apply_accept, @Equiv.symm_symm]
One of the lemmas above could be a duplicate.
If that's not the case try reordering lemmas or adding @[priority].
```
I found out there's `@[simps foo bar baz]` syntax that lets me specify the projections explicitly.

```suggestion
theorem eval_comap (x : List Î±') : (M.comap f).eval x = M.eval (x.map f) := by simp [eval]
```

```suggestion
theorem accepts_comap : (M.comap f).accepts = List.map f â»Â¹' M.accepts := by
```

```suggestion
theorem evalFrom_reindex (s : Ïƒ') (x : List Î±) :
```

```suggestion
theorem symm_reindex : (reindex (Î± := Î±) g).symm = reindex g.symm := rfl
```

```suggestion
theorem eval_reindex (x : List Î±) : (reindex g M).eval x = g (M.eval x) := by simp [eval]
```

```suggestion
theorem accepts_reindex : (reindex g M).accepts = M.accepts := by
```

```suggestion
theorem comap_reindex : (reindex g M).comap f = reindex g (M.comap f) := by simp [comap, reindex]
```

```suggestion
theorem evalFrom_comap (s : Ïƒ) (x : List Î±') :
```

```suggestion
theorem mem_acceptsFrom {start : Ïƒ} {x : List Î±} :
    x âˆˆ M.acceptsFrom start â†” M.evalFrom start x âˆˆ M.accept := by rfl
```
Btw should that lemma be simp?

As [discussed on Zulip](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/144837-PR-reviews/topic/.2311372.20DFA.2EacceptsFrom.2C.20DFA.2Emap.2C.20DFA.2Eequiv/near/427126311), I added some notes on this to the header docs.
I will leave this conversation unresolved for the simp issue

```suggestion
theorem mem_accepts {x : List Î±} : x âˆˆ M.accepts â†” M.eval x âˆˆ M.accept := by rfl
```
Similarly, should that be simp?
I think you can be more precise than "transforms"

I added some more detail â€“ LMK what you think!

```lean
/--
`M.comap f` pulls back the alphabet of `M` along `f`. In other words, it applies `f` to the input
before passing it to `M`.
-/
```
Looks good!
@digama0, this is a good example of situation where we really want nested `where` notation
Or  `step s a := g.symm (M.step (g s) a)` notation within `{}`
Yep, I remember trying both of those syntaxes and realizing neither work ðŸ˜¢
I would call the argument just `(s : Ïƒ)`. The current name has a potential for confusion with `M.start`.
I agree that I currently read it as a declaration name, not a variable name.
That's what I meant, thanks for putting it into appropriate words!
Thanks, renamed to `s`.
Some tag?
See https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/11372#discussion_r1527500415
I am confused by explicit arguments being inserted from `variable`. Afaik this is a matter of style and you can keep it your way.
I agree it is quite confusing. I prefer to get exactly the implicit arguments from `variable` statements

This is exactly what I would do, but I don't want to impose my style on others so much. I guess if I really care about it, I should make a RFC for a convention to use `variable` only with `{}` and `[]` and possibly a linter for that, which does not belong to this PR. So @lambda-fairy feel free to ignore this comment. At this moment, this style issue is up to you.
I don't really mind either way. I've changed it to be more explicit.
The `g` first appears in `def reindex`.
I am a bit suspicious that somebody might later need a more general version than `Ïƒ â‰ƒ Ïƒ'` but I don't mind keeping this definition as it is.
What would the more general version look like?

In my project, I ended up needing this construction:
https://github.com/madvorak/chomsky/blob/a27e2145c36b0a96faf405cb415d020dae97b04a/Grammars/Classes/Unrestricted/Basics/Lifting.lean#L35

The explanation (but written for Lean 3) is here:
https://arxiv.org/abs/2302.06420 (page 6)

I don't have a particular argument why something similar should be useful for DFAs, just a gut feeling.
The analogy is a bit obfuscated by the fact that what you call `Ïƒ` is bundled into the structure in my project.
I guess it might come handy when proving that regular expressions and DFAs are equivalent (TODO in `RegularExpressions.lean`).
However, it would probably be done on the `NFA` structure, so irrelevant for now I guess.
I don't know what `simps` does, so I will leave this line for someone else to review.
It's okay
Thanks for the check!
Why is `(g.symm s)` better than `(g.invFun s)` in the statement? The proof would stay the same.
`.invFun` should never appear in any statement
The current statement is interpreted as `(reindex g M).evalFrom s x = g (M.evalFrom (g.symm.toFun s) x)` afaik.

Yeah, I think this follows the same reasoning as `.toFun`.

There is also a simp lemma that rewrites to `.symm`: https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Logic/Equiv/Defs.html#Equiv.invFun_as_coe
I don't want to argue against the current version. Just tell me why we don't go with the more elementary version. I am not asking you to change it. Just please explain it to me.

> The current statement is interpreted as `(reindex g M).evalFrom s x = g (M.evalFrom (g.symm.toFun s) x)` afaik.

No that's not right. It's interpreted as `(reindex g M).evalFrom s x = â‡‘g (M.evalFrom (â‡‘g.symm s) x)` where `â‡‘` is `FunLike.coe`.

`g.invFun` is not used because we've decided to use `â‡‘g.symm` instead as it gives access to more API. That's it, really.

I believe the reason is that there are many more lemmas for `.symm`. The only lemmas I could find for `.invFun` are those that convert it to `.symm`.

Also, because `Equiv.invFun_as_coe` is a simp lemma, its RHS (`â‡‘e.symm`) is considered the normal form. I'm not 100% sure on this, but it'll probably trigger a linter warning if we use `invFun` instead.
Thank you very much for your explanation! This is completely reasonable.
I don't think it depends on the question above, assuming the question above also talks about `accepts` vs `acceptsFrom`
I've removed that sentence.

```suggestion
## TODO

```

```suggestion
def comap (f : Î±' â†’ Î±) (M : DFA Î± Ïƒ) : DFA Î±' Ïƒ where
```
so that `comap f` makes sense

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: DFA.acceptsFrom, DFA.map, DFA.equiv
